case_vignette: A 65-year-old Asian woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. On questioning, she has had occasional night sweats during the past 2 months. She has not had fevers or weight loss. Seven months ago, she had an acute myocardial infarction and was treated with percutaneous coronary intervention. She has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 37 years. Current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, ramipril, metoprolol, and esomeprazole. She is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (207 lbs); BMI is 29.7 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 145/80 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows an S4. There is a nontender skin lesion near the right large toenail. A photograph of the lesion is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing occasional night sweats during the past two months.
Have you noticed any new or changing skin lesions or rashes?
Yes, there is a nontender skin lesion near my right large toenail.
What does the skin lesion look like in terms of color, size, and shape?
I'm sorry, but I can only tell you that there is a skin lesion near my right large toenail; I don't have details about its color, size, or shape.
Have you recently experienced any significant weight loss, fevers, or swollen lymph nodes?
No, I have not had fevers or weight loss, and there's no mention of swollen lymph nodes.
Do you have any existing medical conditions, or are you currently taking any medications?

Yes, I have hypertension, hyperlipidemia, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and I had an acute myocardial infarction seven months ago. I am currently taking aspirin, atorvastatin, ramipril, metoprolol, and esomeprazole.
Does anyone in your family have a history of skin cancer or other cancers?
I haven't mentioned any family history of skin cancer or other cancers.
Final Diagnosis: Acral lentiginous melanoma
